[[Gibson Flying V]] }} '''Joe Bonamassa''' (born May 8, 1977){{cite web|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=enlos7Ykq4wC&pg=SA8-PA51 |title=Guitar - Ernie Jackson - Google Boeken |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=2014-02-22}} is an [[United States|American]] [[blues rock]] musician, singer and songwriter. ==Influences== {{original research|section|date=December 2013}} Unlike other successful blues-rock guitarists, Bonamassa's influences are British and Irish blues acts, rather than American artists. Comparing the music in the United States to the "European" versions of the blues, Bonamassa found the English blues - fostered by the [[Jeff Beck Group]], Eric Clapton and the Irish blues player [[Rory Gallagher]] - to be far more interesting to him than the original [[Delta blues]] players. In an interview in ''[[Guitarist (magazine)|Guitarist]]'' magazine (issue 265), he cited the three albums that had the biggest influence on his playing: [[John Mayall & the Bluesbreakers]] with Eric Clapton (the [[Beano album]]), Rory Gallagher's ''[[Irish Tour]]'' and ''[[Goodbye (Cream album)|Goodbye]]'' by [[Cream (band)|Cream]]. He also stated [[Stevie Ray Vaughan]]'s ''[[Texas Flood]]'' was a big influence at a young age. He also listed the early blues playing of [[Jethro Tull (band)|Jethro Tull]] as one of his influences, putting both [[Martin Barre]] and [[Mick Abrahams]] as important musicians to him.http://www.bluesinbritain.org/joe-bonamassa-interview/http://guitarinternational.com/2010/12/28/joe-bonamassa-talks-influences-touring-and-gear/ His first solo album was named after and includes a cover version of [[Jethro Tull]]'s "A New Day Yesterday" from their album ''[[Stand Up (Jethro Tull album)|Stand Up]]''. [[File:JoeBonamassaStaffordTX.jpg|thumb|220px|right|Bonamassa performing in Stafford, Texas, 2007]] He elaborated further on his influences in the interview: {{blockquote|"You know, my heroes were the columbine guys – [[Paul Kossoff]], [[Peter Green (musician)|Peter Green]], Eric Clapton. There’s so many – there’s [[Gary Moore]], Rory Gallagher – another [[Irish people|Irish]] musician who played the same things, but don’t tell him that. But those guys were my guys – [[Jeff Beck]], [[Jimmy Page]]. There’s a certain sophistication to their approach to the blues that I really like, more so than the American blues that I was listening to. B. B. King’s a big influence – he’s probably my biggest traditional influence. I love Muddy Waters, Robert Johnson and [[T-Bone Walker]] and stuff like that, but I couldn’t sit down… I was always forcing myself to listen to whole records by them, where I’d rather listen to [[Humble Pie (band)|Humble Pie]] do "I'm Ready" than Muddy Waters, you know? I think, the English interpretation of the blues just hit me a lot better, you know?"}} And in his October 2008 interview with ''[[Express & Star]]'': {{blockquote|“When I heard [[Paul Kossoff|Kossoff]] playing "Mr. Big" and when I heard Clapton playing "[[Cross Road Blues|Crossroads]]" and when I heard Rory Gallagher playing "[[Cradle Rock]]", I was like, 'This is way cooler'.... "British blues are my thing. When I heard [[Rod Stewart]] and the [[Jeff Beck Group]] singing "Let Me Love You", it changed my life. I knew exactly what I wanted to do. Those are my influences".}} Joe Bonamassa had appeared in Eric Clapton's Crossroads Guitar Festival 2010 alongside Robert Randolph, Pino Daniele. ==Discography== {{Main|Joe Bonamassa discography}} ;Solo studio albums *''[[A New Day Yesterday (Joe Bonamassa album)|A New Day Yesterday]]'' (2000) *''[[So, It's Like That]]'' (2002) *''[[Blues Deluxe]]'' (2003) *''[[Had to Cry Today (album)|Had to Cry Today]]'' (2004) *''[[You & Me (Joe Bonamassa album)|You & Me]]'' (2006) *''[[Sloe Gin (album)|Sloe Gin]]'' (2007) *''[[The Ballad of John Henry (album)|The Ballad of John Henry]]'' (2009) *''[[Black Rock (Joe Bonamassa Album)|Black Rock]]'' (2010) *''[[Dust Bowl (album)|Dust Bowl]]'' (2011) *''[[Driving Towards the Daylight]]'' (2012) ;Live Albums *''[[A New Day Yesterday Live]]'' (2002) *''[[Shepherds Bush Empire (album)|Shepherds Bush Empire]]'' (2007) *''[[Live from Nowhere in Particular]]'' (2008) *''[[Live from the Royal Albert Hall (Joe Bonamassa album)|Live from the Royal Albert Hall]]'' (2009) *''Beacon Theatre: Live from New York'' (2012) *''An Acoustic Evening at The Vienna Opera House'' (2013) *''Live In Amsterdam'' (together with [[Beth Hart]]) (2014) *''Tour De Force -
